Authors: Zhou Y., Levy J.I., Evans J.S., Hammitt J.K.
Title: The influence of geographic location on population exposure to emissions from power plants throughout China
Affiliations: Harvard School of Public Health, Landmark Center, 401 Park Drive, Boston, MA 02216, United States; Harvard School of Public Health, Landmark Center, P.O. Box 15677, Boston, MA 02215, United States; Harvard Center for Risk Analysis, 718 Huntington Ave., Boston, MA 02115, United States
Authors with affiliations: Zhou, Y., Harvard School of Public Health, Landmark Center, 401 Park Drive, Boston, MA 02216, United States; Levy, J.I., Harvard School of Public Health, Landmark Center, P.O. Box 15677, Boston, MA 02215, United States; Evans, J.S., Harvard Center for Risk Analysis, 718 Huntington Ave., Boston, MA 02115, United States; Hammitt, J.K., Harvard Center for Risk Analysis, 718 Huntington Ave., Boston, MA 02115, United States
Abstract: This analysis seeks to evaluate the influence of emission source location on population exposure in China to fine particles and sulfur dioxide. We use the concept of intake fraction, defined as the fraction of material or its precursor released from a source that is eventually inhaled or ingested by a population. We select 29 power-plant sites throughout China and estimate annual average intake fractions at each site, using identical source characteristics to isolate the influence of geographic location. In addition, we develop regression models to interpret the intake fraction values and allow for extrapolation to other sites. To model the concentration increase due to emissions from selected power plants, we used a detailed long-range atmospheric dispersion model, CALPUFF. Primary fine particles have the highest average intake fraction (1 × 10- 5), followed by sulfur dioxide (5 × 10- 6), sulfate from sulfur dioxide (4 × 10 - 6), and nitrate from nitrogen oxides (4 × 10- 6). For all pollutants, the intake fractions span approximately an order of magnitude across sites. In the regression analysis, the independent variables are meteorological proxies (such as climate region and precipitation) and population at various distances from the source. We find that population terms can explain a substantial percentage of variability in the intake fraction for all pollutants (R2 between 0.86 and 0.95 across pollutants), with a significant modifying influence of meteorological regime. Near-source population is more important for primary coarse particles while population at medium to long distance is more important for primary fine particles and secondary particles. A significant portion of intake fraction (especially for secondary particles and primary fine particles) occurs beyond 500 km of the source, emphasizing the need for detailed long-range dispersion modeling. These findings demonstrate that intake fractions for power plants in China can be estimated with reasonable precision and summarized using simple regression models. The results should be useful for informing future decisions about power-plant locations and controls. © 2005 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Air pollution; Atmospheric dispersion modeling; China; Intake fraction; Particulate matter; Power plant

Authors: Zhu X., Van Ierland E.
Title: The enlargement of the European Union: Effects on trade and emissions of greenhouse gases
Affiliations: Environmental Economics and Natural Resources Group, Wageningen University, PO Box 8130, 6700 EW, Wageningen, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Zhu, X., Environmental Economics and Natural Resources Group, Wageningen University, PO Box 8130, 6700 EW, Wageningen, Netherlands; Van Ierland, E., Environmental Economics and Natural Resources Group, Wageningen University, PO Box 8130, 6700 EW, Wageningen, Netherlands
Abstract: With the gradual accession of various Central and Eastern European Countries (CEECs) to the European Union (EU), international trade between the EU and the CEECs will change as a result of trade liberalisation and the mobility of production factors within the EU. The EU and most of the CEECs have already committed themselves to reduce by 2008-2012 their emissions of greenhouse gases (GHGs) by 8% compared to the 1990 level. This paper reports on an investigation of the potential consequences of the enlargement of the EU and of the emission reduction target set by the Kyoto Protocol on the sectoral production patterns and international trade. A comparative-static general equilibrium model was developed to examine the impacts under different scenarios. For illustrative purposes, two regions (the EU and the CEECs) and three categories of goods and services (agricultural goods, industrial goods, and services) were included. The model was calibrated by the 1998 data. The model was subsequently applied to study the effects of free trade, the mobility of factors and the environmental constraints on production and international trade in light of the enlargement of the EU. We show that in this specific context, free trade is beneficial to economic welfare and does not necessarily increase emissions of greenhouse gases. The mobility of factors also increases economic welfare, but in the case of fixed production technology it may harm the environment through more emissions of GHGs.
Author Keywords: Environment; EU enlargement; General equilibrium model; Kyoto Protocol; Trade
Index Keywords: emission; European Union; Kyoto Protocol

Authors: Zimmermann F., Matschullat J., Brüggemann E., Pleßow K., Wienhaus O.
Title: Temporal and elevation-related variability in precipitation chemistry from 1993 to 2002, eastern Erzgebirge, Germany
Affiliations: TU Bergakademie Freiberg, Interdisziplinäres Ökologisches Zentrum, Brennhausgasse 14, D-09599 Freiberg, Germany; Leibniz-Institut für Troposphärenforschung, Leipzig, Germany; TU Darmstadt, Institut für Angewandte Geowissenschaften, Fachgebiet Umweltmineralogie, Schnittspahnstr. 9, D-64287 Darmstadt, Germany; TU Dresden, Institut für Pflänzenchemie und Holzchemie, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Zimmermann, F., TU Darmstadt, Institut für Angewandte Geowissenschaften, Fachgebiet Umweltmineralogie, Schnittspahnstr. 9, D-64287 Darmstadt, Germany; Matschullat, J., TU Bergakademie Freiberg, Interdisziplinäres Ökologisches Zentrum, Brennhausgasse 14, D-09599 Freiberg, Germany; Brüggemann, E., Leibniz-Institut für Troposphärenforschung, Leipzig, Germany; Pleßow, K., TU Bergakademie Freiberg, Interdisziplinäres Ökologisches Zentrum, Brennhausgasse 14, D-09599 Freiberg, Germany; Wienhaus, O., TU Dresden, Institut für Pflänzenchemie und Holzchemie, Germany
Abstract: The Erzgebirge, part of the so-called former "Black Triangle", used to represent the strongest regional air pollution of Central Europe. To test the hypothesis of deposition enhancement with height, an altitudinal gradient along a N-S transect from the Elbe river lowlands to the Erzgebirge summit was chosen to investigate chemical composition, elevation-related variability, temporal changes, and seasonal patterns of ion concentrations from 1993 to 2002. The following questions were to be answered: (1) Which role does orography play on the composition of precipitation?, (2) Does fog occurrence overrule the orographic influence?, (3) Are there changes in the past 10 years, and if so, why?, (4) Do relevant seasonal changes occur and why? Air streams from westerly and to a lesser degree south-easterly directions prevail. The average precipitation was ion-poor (23 μS cm-1) and acidic (pH 4.5). Sulphate still was the dominant anion (52.3-59.9 μeq L-1), while NH4+ determined the cations (41.9-62.2 μeq L -1). Ion concentrations decreased with altitude to about 735 m a.s.l. and subsequently increased. The seeder-feeder effect largely explains the chemical composition of precipitation; enhanced in winter through snow crystals. Sub-cloud scavenging does not explain the observed patterns. Fog occurrence enhanced the observed effects at higher altitudes. Deposition amounts doubled from the lowlands to the Erzgebirge summit. From 1993 to 2002, acidity decreased by about 50%, mainly due to reduced SO2-emissions. © Springer 2006.

Authors: Zorko A., Arčon D., Lappas A., Jagličić Z.
Title: Magnetic versus non-magnetic doping effects in the Haldane chain compound PbNi2v2O8
Affiliations: Jožef Stefan Institute, Jamova 39, 1000 Ljubljana, Slovenia; Institute of Electronic Structure and Laser, Foundation for Research and Technology - Hellas, PO Box 1527, 71110 Heraklion, Crete, Greece; Institute of Mathematics, Physics and Mechanics, Jadranska 19, 1000 Ljubljana, Slovenia
Authors with affiliations: Zorko, A., Jožef Stefan Institute, Jamova 39, 1000 Ljubljana, Slovenia; Arčon, D., Jožef Stefan Institute, Jamova 39, 1000 Ljubljana, Slovenia; Lappas, A., Institute of Electronic Structure and Laser, Foundation for Research and Technology - Hellas, PO Box 1527, 71110 Heraklion, Crete, Greece; Jagličić, Z., Institute of Mathematics, Physics and Mechanics, Jadranska 19, 1000 Ljubljana, Slovenia
Abstract: Study of an impurity-driven phase transition into a magnetically ordered state in the spin-liquid Haldane chain compound PbNi2V 2O8 is presented. Both macroscopic magnetization as well as 15V nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) measurements reveal that the magnetic nature of dopants has a crucial role in determining the stability of the induced long-range magnetic order. In the case of non-magnetic (Mg 2+ doping at the Ni2+ sites (S = 1), a metamagnetic transition is observed in relatively low magnetic fields. On the other hand, the magnetic order in magnetically (Co2+) doped compounds survives at much higher magnetic fields and temperatures. We attribute this feature to a significant anisotropic impurity-host magnetic interaction. The NMR measurements confirm that the staggered magnetic moments liberated next to the impurity sites, are the reason for the magnetic ordering. In addition, differences in the broadening of NMR spectra and the increase of nuclear spin-lattice relaxation in doped samples indicate an impurity-dependent character for the dominant electron-spin correlations; the latter begin to develop at rather high temperatures with respect to the antiferromagnetic phase-transition temperature. © IOP Publishing Ltd and Deutsche Physikalische Gesellschaft.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans; State of Missouri
Abstract: EPA is approving a SIP submission by the State of Missouri, which revises the Construction Permits Required rule and takes no action on the revisions made to the Emissions Banking and Trading rule. A proposal was published on 4/14/2006 in the Federal Register, and no comments were received. As proposed, EPA is approving most of the revisions to the Construction Permits Required rule because the revisions incorporate, by reference, the Federal New Source Review reforms, published in the Federal Register on 12/31/2002. As requested by Missouri, EPA is not acting on portions of the state rule relating to Clean Unit Exemptions, Pollution Control Projects, and a portion of the record keeping provisions for the actual-to-projected-actual emissions projections test. This final rule is effective 7/27/2006. The subjects listed in 40 CFR Part 52 include environmental protection, air pollution control, CO, incorporation by reference, intergovernmental relations, lead, NO2, O3, particulate matter, reporting and recordkeeping requirements, SOx, and VOC.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Regulation of fuel and fuel additives: Reformulated gasoline requirements for former severe nonattainment areas under the 1-hour ozone standard that were redesignated to attainment for the 1-hour standard prior to its revocation, and which are current nonattainment areas for the 8-hr ozone standard
Abstract: EPA is seeking comment on two alternative proposals regarding reformulated gasoline (RFG) requirements for an area formerly classified as a severe ozone non-attainment area under the 1-hr ozone NAAQS that was redesignated to attainment for that standard before its revocation, and which is currently designated as non-attainment for the 8-hr ozone standard. Under the first option, this area would be required to use federal RFG at least until it is redesignated to attainment for the 8-hr NAAQS. Under the second option, the State could request the removal of RFG, and EPA would grant such a request upon a demonstration that removal would not result in loss of any RFC-related emission reductions relied upon in the SIP for ozone. Atlanta is the only area that falls within the scope of this proposal. All public comments must be received on or before 8/22/2006.

Authors: Committee on State Practices in Setting Mobile Source Emissions Standards, Board on Environmental Studies and Toxicology, Division on Earth and Life Studies, National Research Council
Title: State and Federal Standards for mobile-source emissions
Source title: State and Federal Standards for Mobile-Source Emissions
Authors with affiliations: Committee on State Practices in Setting Mobile Source Emissions Standards; Board on Environmental Studies and Toxicology; Division on Earth and Life Studies; National Research Council
Abstract: Air pollutant emissions from mobile sources have been regulated for almost half a century. During this time, the focus has largely been on tightening emissions standards for on-road vehicles and engines, particularly passenger cars and small trucks (light-duty vehicles). Light-duty vehicle emissions control grew out of research that implicated the increasing use of vehicles in the deterioration of air quality conditions in the 1950s in Southern California. Control of motor vehicle emissions began in the early 1960s with the introduction of positive crankcase ventilation, a simple approach consisting of a hose and valve that reduced the venting of uncombusted gases to the atmosphere. From that simple beginning, light-duty-vehicle emissions control evolved to today's complex regulation of fuel properties, exhaust emissions, and evaporative emissions, which require the use of sophisticated engine and emissions-control technologies. These strategies enabled per-mile-exhaust emissions of new, properly operating light-duty vehicles to decrease by 95-99% in 2004 compared with emissions of 1967 model-year vehicles. The focus of mobile-source emissions control expanded to include on-road heavy-duty engines and later nonroad engines. The broadening in regulatory attention arose from the increasing fraction of mobile-source emissions that come from sources other than light-duty vehicles and the relative lack of emissions controls on these sources. On-road heavy-duty-vehicle engines were first regulated for air pollutants in the 1970s, and engines used in off-road applications were first regulated in the mid-1990s. Over the next decade, regulations already approved for new sources will substantially reduce emissions from on-road diesel vehicles, nonroad diesel engines, and gasoline-powered nonroad engines. © 2006 by the National Academy of Sciences. All rights reserved.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Industry news: Toray signs long-term prepreg supply deal with Boeing
Abstract: Boeing Inc has awarded Toray Industries Inc, Japan, a $3 billion contract for the supply of carbon fiber prepreg for use on the twin-aisle B787 Dreamliner aircraft. Under the terms of the contract, Toray Composites (America) will produce and sell carbon fiber fabric and epoxy resin prepregs for use in the 787's fuselage structure. In anticipation of the new business, Toray has expanded its prepreg production capacity in Fredericksen, Washington, USA and is also building a carbon fiber plant in Ehime Prefecture, Japan.
Index Keywords: aircraft; carbon fiber; company information; epoxy resin; investment; joint venture; prepreg; production; supplier

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Bringing particulates down in the mountains
Abstract: A 2003 Mountain Master Development Plan has been introduced in California by Mountain Utilities where it started upgrades of services and capacity to prepare for expected growth in its customer base. Two companies, Miratech and Cashman have helped the country to meet strict particulate matter (PM) emissions standards. The planned upgrades included replacing two of the six Mountain Utilities Caterpillar D399 engines with a single engine, the Cat 3516C. The Cat 3516C engine was designed for a low output of exhaust particulate matter. Miratech provided Mountain Utilities with CombiKat diesel particulate filter that proved its ability to reduce PM by 85% or more in conditions reflecting real-world operation. The CombiKat's sulfur-tolerant catalyst allows collected diesel PM to oxidize on the filter at exhaust temperatures above 700° F without an additional heat source. In addition to PM compliance, the CombiKat also provides noise reduction.
Index Keywords: Air pollution control; Diesel engines; Particulate emissions; Regional planning; Regulatory compliance; Standards; California by Mountain Utilities; Heat source; Single engine; Elementary particles

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: The threat of a "Coal Rush"
Abstract: Energy companies are planning to build over 150 coal-fired power plants across the United States. The increase in coal demand would increase the environmental devastation caused by coal mining, which has already affected more than seven percent of Appalachian forests and resulted in the release of hundreds of millions of pounds of toxic chemicals. This increase may cause a danger posed by global warming and have worst consequences. To avoid these problems, US is planning to invest in energy efficiency and wind energy that could help in developing 110 gigawatts of the best wind energy locations in the western US, which could produce electricity at an overall cost comparable to coal. It is suggested that the leaders should reduce carbon dioxide pollution over time and should develop programs on energy efficiency and renewable energy resources. Public money should not be spent on coal technology.
Index Keywords: Coal mines; Energy efficiency; Environmental impact; Global warming; Power plants; Renewable energy resources; Strategic planning; Toxic materials; Wind power; Coal fired power plants; Coal technology; Environmental devastation; Toxic chemicals; Energy policy

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: ETS seeks carbon credibility
Abstract: The carbon market saw a fall in prices with the release of data for installations participating in the European Union's Emission Trading Scheme (ETS). The commission's registry shows that the 21 Member States that have completed the reporting process emitted 67.5m t less carbon dioxide than they were allocated in the 2005 trading period. This resulted in a 3.4 percent surplus of emission allowance and caused prices to fall from around €13/t carbon dioxide to €8/t carbon dioxide in one day. The release of this data is an important milestones in the ETS, as the scheme is the primary concern of the European Commission's plan to meet the Kyoto commitments. The level of surplus allowances have raised questions as the robustness of the market and allocation of emission allowances in the National Allocation Plans (NAPs). A number of environmental groups have expressed concern that the Member States have granted far too generous emission allowances.
Index Keywords: Carbon dioxide; Environmental impact; Gas emissions; Marketing; Emission Trading Scheme (ETS); Kyoto commitments; National Allocation Plans (NAP); Carbon

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Environmental news: News briefs: Fresh air problems for Europe
Abstract: Air pollution rose above recommended levels in all 20 European cities sampled for a European Environment Agency survey in 2000. Air-quality limit values were often exceeded, especially in streets and other urban hotspots. Traffic-related air pollution is still one of the most pressing problems in urban areas. Most of the traffic-related emissions were in the fine particulates range (below the PM2.5 scale). EU lawmakers are currently considering new rules that would limit emissions of particulate matter by diesel cars to 5 mg/km.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Concrete for a sustainable future - A report on the Institute of Concrete Technology (ICT) convention 2006
Abstract: A report on The Institute of Concrete Technology (ICT) Convention 2006 discussing the future of concrete is presented. The discussion sessions included a discussion about how accounting of carbon dioxide was done. The difficulties of following all materials back to their sources and measuring the impact of their winning on local economies and transport on the total environmental load were also raised. Danny Lawrence,Lafarge Cement, gave evidence that the cement industry has already achieved its share of the reduction in carbon dioxide emissions agreed at Kyoto. The assumptions used give the conclusion that concrete and brick structures represent less impact on global warning in the long run than timber-based structures. The stress was on the potential working life of concrete which allows completed buildings to be recycled thereby reducing the total impact of concrete structures over their lifetimes.
Index Keywords: Brick; Carbon dioxide; Environmental impact; Particulate emissions; Recycling; Structural loads; Brick structures; Carbon dioxide emissions; Global warning; Timber-based structures; Concrete industry

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: California State nonroad engine and vehicle pollution control standards; Authorization of large off-road spark-ignition engine standards, notice of decision
Abstract: EPA, pursuant to section 209(e) of the Clean Air Act, 42 U.S.C. 7543(b), is authorizing California to enforce its regulations setting emission standards and other requirements for large off-road spark-ignition engines. Section 209(e)(1) of the Act addresses the permanent preemption of any State, or political subdivision thereof, from adopting or attempting to enforce any standard or other requirement relating to the control of emissions for certain new nonroad engines or vehicles. Section 209(e)(2) of the Act allows the Administrator to grant California authorization to enforce state standards for new nonroad engines or vehicles that are not listed under Section 209(e)(1), subject to certain restrictions.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Revisions to the California State Implementation Plan, South Coast Air Quality Management District
Abstract: EPA is proposing to approve revisions to the South Coast Air Quality Management District's (SCAQMD) portion of the California SIP. These revisions concern NOx, and SOx emissions from facilities emitting ≥ 4 ton/yr of NOx or SOx in the year 1990 or subsequent year under the SCAQMD's Regional Clean Air Incentives Market program. EPA is proposing to approve local rules to regulate these emission sources under the Clean Air Act. EPA is taking comments on this proposal and plan to follow with a final action. Any comments must arrive by 6/15/2006.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans and operating permits program; State of Missouri
Abstract: EPA is approving revisions to the Missouri SIP and Operating Permits Program. EPA is approving a revision to the Missouri rule entitled "Submission of Emission Data, Emission Fees, and Process Information". This revision will ensure consistency between the state and the federally-approved rules. This direct final rule will be effective 7/11/2006, without further notice, unless EPA receives adverse comment by 6/12/2006. If adverse comment is received, EPA will publish a timely withdrawal of the direct final rule in the Federal Register informing the public that the rule will not take effect. List of subjects in 40 CFR Part 52 includes environmental protection, air pollution control, CO, incorporation by reference, NO2, ozone, particulate matter, SOx, VOC.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans; carbon monoxide maintenance plan, conformity budgets, emissions inventories; State of New Jersey
Abstract: EPA is proposing to approve a SIP revision submitted by the State of New Jersey, which will establish an updated 10-yr CO maintenance plan for the Nine Not-Classified Areas in the State and Camden County. This document proposes to approve revisions to the CO, NOx, VOC, and PM2.5 motor vehicle emissions budgets for Northern New Jersey. This document also proposes to approve revisions to the general conformity budget for McGuire Air Force Base and the 2002 base year emissions inventory. Comments must be received on or before 6/8/2006.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans; Las Vegas carbon monoxide attainment plan
Abstract: EPA proposes to approve a revised attainment plan for the Las Vegas Valley CO nonattainment area on the condition that Clark County and the State of Nevada withdraw the 2030 motor vehicle emission budget, or, in the alternative, to disapprove the plan. The revised attainment plan includes revised base year and future year emissions inventories and a revised demonstration of continued attainment of the CO NAAQS in Las Vegas Valley through 2030 based on the most recent emissions models and planning assumptions, and establishes new motor vehicle emissions budgets. Comments must be received on or before 6/8/2006.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Government & policy concentrates: EPA is sued over carbon emissions
Abstract: A coalition of states, cities, and conservation groups is challenging the Bush Administration's decision not to limit CO2 emissions from new power plants and industrial facilities across the nation. The Clean Air Act requires that EPA review and revise emissions standards for new stationary pollution sources every 8 yr to ensure that they protect public health and the environment. In February, EPA issued new source performance standards but declined to regulate CO2, the principal greenhouse gas. EPA argues that the Clean Air Act does not authorize it to regulate emissions to reduce global warming and maintains that there are not enough scientific data to support such a move. However, in lawsuits filed in the US Court of Appeals in Washington, D.C., the petitioners assert that EPA has clear authority under the law to set limits on emissions linked to global warming.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Developing a European dimension
Abstract: Shell and Statoil's plans for an emission-free gas-fired power station were announced on the same day that the European Commission unveiled its road map for a new energy strategy. The commission report highlights the need for a competitive single energy market in Europe, backed by a strategy aimed at achieving reliable deliveries. Such security of supply will be accomplished through improved technology, infrastructure and cooperation with neighbouring energy-rich regions. Other goals are reduced consumption, lower energy prices and effective action to counter serious climate change and environmental damage on a global basis. European interests see an opportunity for many of these objectives to be exemplified through the Shell-Statoil project.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Cummins debuts QSK50 mining engine in Europe
Abstract: Cummins has launched a 16-cylinder QSK50 diesel mining engine, which is certified to the United States EPA Tier 2 exhaust emissions regulations, at Intermart 2006 in Paris for large mining haul trucks, excavators and wheeled loaders. QSK50 is available with two-stage turbocharging for high-altitude mining applications as a standard version. The engine features Cummins' advanced in-cylinder emissions solution designed to reduce OEM installation impact and minimize re-engineering. A further focus of Cummins' exhibits at intermat included engines for compact and mini equipment, with special emphasis on its A Series of sub 1 L/cyl diesels in a power range from 23 to 45 kW.
Index Keywords: Diesel engines; Engines; Exhaust gases; Mining machinery; Trucks; Cummins (CO); Emissions regulations; Wheeled loaders; Mining equipment

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Inclusion of Delaware and New Jersey in the Clean Air interstate rule
Abstract: EPA is finalizing regulations to include Delaware and New Jersey in the Clean Air Interstate Rule (CAIR) for fine particles (PM2.5). In the CAIR, EPA determined that upwind States that contribute ≥ 0.2 μg/cu m to a downwind PM2.5 nonattainment area are potentially deemed to be contributing significantly to nonattainment in the downwind State. The EPA proposed to augment the analytical approach used in the CAIR by supplementing the air quality step of the contribution analysis. Thus, EPA proposed that Delaware and New Jersey should be covered by the CAIR for annual SO2 and NOx requirements and EPA is finalizing the regulation to include these States in the CAIR for PM2.5. This final rule is effective on 6/27/2006.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Rule to reduce interstate transport of fine particulate matter and ozone (Clean Air Interstate Rule): Reconsideration
Abstract: On 5/12/2005, EPA published the final "Rule to Reduce Interstate Transport of Fine Particulate Matter and Ozone". In this action, EPA found that 28 States and the District of Columbia contribute significantly to nonattainment of, and interfere with maintenance by, downwind States with respect to the NAAQS for fine particles and/or 8-hr ozone. The CAIR requires these upwind States to revise their SIP to include control measures to reduce emissions of SO2 and/or NOx. By reducing upwind emissions of SO2 and NOx, CAIR will assist downwind PM2.5 and 8-hr ozone nonattainment areas in achieving the NAAQS. This rule is effective 6/27/2006.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans; State of Missouri
Abstract: EPA is proposing to approve a SIP submission by the state of Missouri, which revises the Construction Permits Required rule, and EPA is taking no action on the revisions made to the Emissions Banking and Trading rule. Missouri requested EPA not to act on references to Clean Unit Exemptions, Pollution Control Projects, and the record keeping provisions for the actual-to-projected-actual emissions projections. Missouri requests no action on these provisions because of the 6/24/2005 US Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit's decision. Comments must be received on or before 5/15/2006. List of subjects in 40 CFR Part 52 includes environmental protection, air pollution control, CO, NO2, ozone, particulate matter, VOC, etc.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Revisions to the California state implementation plan, San Joaquin Valley Unified Air Pollution Control District and South Coast Air Quality Management District
Abstract: EPA is taking direct final action to approve revisions to the San Joaquin Valley Unified Air Pollution Control District and South Coast Air Quality Management District portions of the California SIP. These revisions concern particulate matter emissions from open burning and VOC emissions from gasoline storage and transfer. EPA is approving local rules that regulate these emission sources under the CAAA. This rule is effective on 6/12/2006 without further notice, unless EPA receives adverse comments by 5/11/2006.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Car industry failing on climate pledge
Abstract: Carmakers are defaulting on their commitment to tackle climate change, as car industry efforts to improve fuel efficiency achieved a significant lower level in 2005 than the rate needed to meet a promise they made to the European Union in 1998. The European Automobile Manufacturers Association (ACEA) committed to the EU in 1998 to reduce the average CO2 emission of new cars sold in 15 EU Member States to 140 grams/km. European manufacturers sold cars that produce 160 grams of CO2 per km in 2005, down only 1 per cent on the 2004. Carmakers require an unprecedented improvement rate of 4.3 per cent per year to meet their commitment.
Index Keywords: Automotive industry; Carbon dioxide; Failure analysis; Fuel systems; Climate pledge; European Automobile Manufacturers Association (ACEA); Industry efforts; Climate change

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Gold East fulfills its ambitions
Abstract: The world's largest fine paper mill, Gold East Paper Dagang, owned by an AP China subsidiary, has added the world's largest fine paper machine Voith Paper PM3, to its two units. Voith includes four-bale dewiring and feed systems with three virgin fiber pulpers, an advanced wet end process, process water system, chemical additives processing and dosing technology. It includes the rejects pulper and treatment, vacuum systems, mixer stations for the pre-coat and top-coat color, and paper roll transport systems. The mill has on-site precipitated calcium carbonate and ground calcium carbonate plants to produce filler. It uses the most advanced SAP system and has introduced Six Sigma and Cycle Time Reduction programs to improve production and services. The facility will be producing over 1.5 million tons per year of paper, most of which is for the local market.
Index Keywords: Natural fibers; Papermaking machinery; Pulp; Wet ends (papermaking machinery); Dosing technology; Fiber pulpers; Mixer stations; Vacuum systems; Paper and pulp industry; Metering Equipment; Paper Mills; Pulps; Wet Ends

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Foreign affairs preemption and state regulation of greenhouse gas emissions
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Global monitor: Big bucks for carbon sequestration
Abstract: The California Energy Commission awarded about $14 million for carbon sequestration projects to be overseen by the West Coast Regional Carbon Sequestration Partnership, Westcarb. Alberta and British Columbia have joined Saskatchewan and Manitoba as Canadian partners in the Regional Carbon Sequestration Partnership (RCSP) program, which is the centerpiece of efforts to validate carbon sequestration technologies and deploy them across North America. Westcarb is focusing on two kinds of carbon sequestration: terrestrial (changing management of forests to enable them to remove more CO2 from the air) and geologic (capturing CO2 produced by industrial plants before it is released and injecting it into leak-proof geologic formations).

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: United Kingdom: Renewable rejection
Abstract: Development of a 67.5 Mw wind farm in Whinash, UK, has been refused following a number of recommendations from the inspector appointed to carry out the inquiry. The application was dismissed because it was felt that the area in which the wind farm would be located would lose its natural beauty, with concern that the Lake District National Park could face difficulties in acquiring future world heritage status. The inspector's recommendations, which were accepted by the UK's secretary of state, highlighted that the developers had overstated their claims for power production and CO2 reductions. Since the recommendations were made, Ofgem, the UK energy regulator, has cited that the cost of abating CO2 with wind turbines is £429/ton, while coal gasification could cost ≥ £20/ton.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Control of air pollution from new motor vehicles: Amendments to the Tier 2 motor vehicle emission regulations
Abstract: EPA is making a revision to the Code of Federal Regulations for the purpose of giving the Iowa Department of Natural Resources (IDNR) full regulatory responsibility for EPA-issued Prevention of Significant Deterioration Permits. IDNR demonstrated state legislative authority to take responsibility for the permits, and demonstrated that resources are available to accomplish full regulatory responsibility. This direct final rule will be effect on 5/30/2006, without further notice, unless EPA receives adverse comment by 5/1/2006. List of subjects in 40 CFR part 52 include environmental protection, air pollution control, CO, incorporation by reference, intergovernmental relations, lead, NO2, ozone, particulate matter, SOx, reporting and recordkeeping requirements, and VOC.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Processing - Quick takes: Completion of Afghan topping plant reported
Abstract: Oxiana Energy Inc has disclosed the completion of a 3000 bpd topping plant at Angot oil field, in the Sar-i-Pol province of northern Afghanistan. Reengineering and reconstruction of the plant began in 2002. It owns the facility with local partner Shamal Inter Neft, which started the project in the early 1990s. Oxiana is awaiting permission under a new Afghan hydrocarbon law to participate in the rehabilitation and development of nearby oil fields, which will provide feedstock for the plant.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Revisions to the Nevada State implementation plan
Abstract: EPA is finalizing approval of revisions to the Nevada SIP. These revisions were proposed in the Federal Register on 9/13/2005 and include definitions, SOx emission regulations, and various other burning regulations. EPA is approving these regulations to regulate these emission sources under the CAAA. This rule is effective on 4/26/2006.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans; North Carolina: Charlotte, Raleigh-Durham, and Winston-Salem areas second 10-year maintenance plan for the carbon monoxide national ambient air quality standard
Abstract: EPA is approving a revision to the North Carolina SIP submitted in final form on 3/23/2005. The SIP revision provides the second 10-yr maintenance plan for the Charlotte, Raleigh-Durham, and Winston-Salem CO Maintenance Areas, which are composed of the following four counties: Mecklenburg (Charlotte Area), Durham and Wake (Raleigh-Durham Area), and Forsyth (Winston-Salem Area). The second 10-yr maintenance plan includes new motor vehicle emission budgets (MVEB) for CO for 2015. In this rulemaking, EPA is providing information on its transportation conformity adequacy determination for new MVEB for 2015 that are contained in the second 10-yr CO maintenance plan for the Charlotte, Raleigh-Durham, and Winston-Salem Areas. This direct final rule is effective on 5/23/2006.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; Maine; 15% and 5% emission reduction plans, inventories, and transportation conformity budgets for the Portland one and eight hour ozone nonattainment areas
Abstract: EPA is approving SIP revisions submitted by the State of Maine. These revisions establish a 15% VOC emission reduction plan, and revised 1990 base year emissions inventory, for the Portland Maine 1-hr ozone nonattainment area. These revisions establish a 5% increment of progress emission reduction plan, 2002 base year inventory, and transportation conformity budget for the Portland Maine 8-hr ozone nonattainment area. This rule is effective on 4/24/2006.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Revisions to the California state implementation plan, San Joaquin Valley Unified Air Pollution Control District
Abstract: EPA is taking direct final action to approve revisions to the San Joaquin Valley Unified Air Pollution Control District portion of the California SIP. These revisions concern VOC emissions from components at petroleum refineries, chemical plants, light crude oil production facilities, and natural gas production and processing facilities. EPA is approving local rules that regulate these emission sources under the Clean Air Act as amended in the CAAA. This rule is effective on 5/22/2006 without further notice, unless EPA receives adverse comments by 4/24/2006.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Outer continental shelf air regulations consistency update for California
Abstract: EPA is proposing to update a portion of the Outer Continental Shelf (OCS) Air Regulations pertaining to the requirements for OCS sources by the Ventura County Air Pollution Control District. The intended effect of approving the OCS requirements is to regulate emissions from OCS sources in accordance with the requirements onshore. The changes to the existing requirements is proposed to be incorporated by reference into the Code of Federal Regulation, and is listed in the appendix to the OCS air regulations. Comments must be received by 4/24/2006.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans; Mississipi prevention of significant deterioration and new source review
Abstract: EPA is proposing to approve revisions to the Mississippi SIP to include changes made to the state's "Permit Regulations for the Construction and Operation of Air Emissions Equipment" and "Regulations for the Prevention of Significant Deterioration of Air Quality". The proposed revisions amend the state permitting rules to address changes to the federal New Source Review (NSR) regulations. EPA's 2002 NSR Reform Rules proposed for inclusion in the Mississippi SIP contain provisions for baseline emissions calculations, an actual-to-projected-actual methodology for calculating emissions changes, options for plant-wide applicability limits, and recordkeeping and reporting requirements. Comments must be received by 4/24/2006.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Adequacy status of the Truckee Meadows (Washoe County, NV) submitted carbon monoxide maintenance plan for transportation conformity purposes
Abstract: In this notice, EPA is notifying the public that the motor vehicle emissions budgets contained in the submitted Redesignation Request and Maintenance Plan for the Truckee Meadows (Washoe County, NV) Carbon Monoxide Nonattainment Area (September 2005) ("Truckee Meadows Carbon Monoxide Redesignation Request and Maintenance Plan") are adequate for transportation conformity purposes. Thus, the Washoe County Regional Transportation Commission and the DOT must use the CO motor vehicle emissions budgets from the submitted plan for future conformity determinations. This determination is effective 3/30/2006.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans; State of Missouri
Abstract: EPA is taking final action to partially approve and partially disapprove portions of the Restriction of Emission of Sulfur Compounds rule into the Missouri SIP. This Missouri rule establishes general requirements for emissions of sulfur compounds from various source categories and establishes specific emissions requirements for certain named sources. EPA is approving most of the revisions to the rule because the changes involve clarifications, updates, and other improvements to the current rule. This action does not include a portion of the rule that regulates ambient concentrations of sulfur compounds, because this provision is not in the current SIP, and EPA does not directly enforce Missouris Air Quality Standards. EPA is disapproving Missouris request to include in the SIP a revision to two source-specific references because the state has not demonstrated that the revisions are protective of the short-term SO2 NAAQS. This rule is effective on 4/12/2006.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans; Alabama: State implementation plan revision
Abstract: EPA is approving revisions to the Alabama SIP, submitted by the Alabama Department of Environmental Management on 9/11/2003. The revisions include modifications to Alabama's open burning rules found at Alabama Administrative Code Chapter 335-3-3-.01. These revisions are part of Alabama's strategy to meet the NAAQS by reducing emissions of VOC and NOx. These rules are intended to help control levels of PM2.5 and O3 precursors that contribute to high O3 and PM2.5 levels. The action is being taken pursuant to section 110 of the Clean Air Act. Written comments must be received on or before 4/10/2006.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans; Alabama: State implementation plan revision
Abstract: EPA is approving revisions to the Alabama SIP, submitted by the Alabama Department of Environmental Management on 9/11/2003. The revisions include modifications to Alabama's open burning rules found at Alabama Administrative Code Chapter 335-3-3-.01. These revisions are part of Alabama's strategy to meet the NAAQS by reducing emissions of VOC and NOx. The action is being taken pursuant to section 110 of the Clean Air Act. This direct final rule is effective 5/8/2006 without further notice, unless EPA receives adverse comment by 4/10/2006.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; Virginia; Amendments to the ambient air quality standards
Abstract: EPA approves a SIP revision submitted by the Commonwealth of Virginia. This revision pertains to the amendments of the Commonwealth's existing ambient air quality standards. The Commonwealth's SIP revision incorporates the 1997 NAAQS for the 8-hr ozone and PM2.5 into the Virginia Regulations for the Control and Abatement for Air Pollution: 9 VAC 5 Chapter 30, Ambient Air Quality Standards. The other SIP revisions incorporated into 9 VAC 5 Chapter 30, are amendments to the ambient air quality standards for SO2, CO, ozone (1-hr), PM10, NO2, and lead to make the state regulation consistent with 40 CFR part 50. This rule is effective on 4/3/2006.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Canberra: Electing the unelectable!
Abstract: The Australian Labor government has outlined an energy policy focusing on long-term national targets of 60% reduction to Australia's year 2000 levels of greenhouse gas emissions by 2050. The government is also committed to Kyoto Protocol on climate change and developing a carbon trading regime in the country. The country has invested in environmentally sustainable policies such as transformation of coal industry and the solar sector. The Labor government has included changes in research and development, depreciation of capital equipment purchase, and provision of fixed research allowance. The country's energy policy includes renewable energy target support growth of clean energy, focusing Australian research on developing renewable energy, and commercializing the energy industry. The Austrailian Labor government has aimed to work with state and private green car industry organizations, and offer environmentally friendly cars.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: China's oil markets
Abstract: China's oil markets have undergone profound changes as demand for a wide range of petroleum products has grown very rapidly. The key factors pushing the demand for oil in the transportation sector in China are the rising incomes of workers and the growing numbers of workers living in big cities. The large shift in China's population from the rural areas to the cities, is causing the rapid growth of the number of potential drivers. These changes, along with high levels of motor vehicles sales and high-way construction, are laying a groundwork for future demand growth. The Chinese government is restructuring its oil industry, to help manage these changes, while complying with national policies to preserve energy independence and protect the environment. New environmental programs targeting emissions and waste disposals are responsible for the growing adoption of clean technologies and practices in all sectors of the petroleum industry.
Index Keywords: Energy management; Industrial management; Petroleum products; Petroleum transportation; Waste disposal; Clean technologies; High-way construction; Oil industry; Transportation sector; Petroleum industry

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: News brief: Gasoline refiners phase out MTBE
Abstract: According to an article in the Baltimore Sun, gasoline refiners will start phasing out MTBE due to an EPA rule. In May, the EPA will no longer specify the oxygen content for clean-burning gasoline in smog-afflicted areas. The air pollution regulations had resulted in MTBE being added to fuel to help reduce smog. While the EPA is not requiring refineries to remove MTBE, many will probably do so due in part to lawsuits filed by homeowners and others with contaminated wells. Leaking UST have contaminated ground water supplies in almost 20 states.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Wood Fiber Council goes to St. Paul
Abstract: The Wood Fiber Employees Joint Legislative Council held a conference at St. Paul to discuss the issues relevant to the timber industry. The council is a joint labor-management organization representing unions and companies in Minnesota's forest products industry. The legislative issues included bonding money for reforestation and forest roads, extensions on state timber sales due to warm winter weather, increasing truck weights to include outbound forest products, and requiring the largest coal fired power plants to reduce the mercury emissions by 90 percent. Legislators shared their views of the legislative session and the status of several bills before the legislature.
Index Keywords: Laws and legislation; Reforestation; Timber; Wood products; Coal fired power plants; Labor management; Mercury emissions; Timber sales; Natural fibers; Climates; Forests; Legislation; Reforestation; Wood Fibers

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Technology lowers NOX and generates renewables credits
Abstract: Babcock Power Environmental has introduced a high-efficiency NOx reduction technology that is a relatively inexpensive alternative to traditional selective catalytic reduction (SCR) systems. The reduction technology can be installed in the low temperature region downstream of flue gas treatment equipment on boilers fired by biomass and other fuels. The challenge was to find a way to install SCR catalyst which requires a minimum of about 575 F to function in the clean flue gas downstream of the existing particulate control system. The new hybrid technology allows small power facilities to economically reduce NOx emissions and garner renewable energy credits in the bargain.
Index Keywords: Biomass; Catalysis; Catalyst selectivity; Flue gases; Particulate emissions; Renewable energy resources; Flue gas treatment; Particulate control system; Selective catalytic reduction (SCR) systems; Nitrogen compounds

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Designer diesel: GTL for the forecourt: If large-scale GTL diesel is the future, it was born here
Abstract: In response to the world's accelerating demand for energy and more stringent environmental legislation, Shell embarked in the early 1970s on extensive research to develop alternative sources of energy and transportation fuels. These efforts resulted in the creation of Shell's proprietary Middle Distillate Synthesis technology, enabling the commercialization of remote gas reserves into exceptionally clean products. The company's first commercial 12,500 bpd GTL plant was commissioned in 1993 at Bintulu, in Sarawak, Malaysia. It was designed to convert 110 million scf/day of natural gas piped ashore from the South China Sea, into high-quality liquid products. The unique properties of Shell GTL products have set new standards in the fuels had specialties markets. The GTL Gasoil fraction, referred to as GTL Fuel, is an attractive option as a transport fuel in major cities struggling with traffic congestion and poor air quality. It significantly reduces local emissions of particulates, NO, CO, and hydrocarbons. Trials were held with both Shell GTL blends with standard diesel and 100% neat fuel in a range of heavy-duty and light-duty vehicles demonstrating significantly lower emissions with no loss of performance.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: State's rules: California - Ports targeted
Abstract: The ports of Los Angeles and Long Beach have the opportunity to voluntarily reduce emissions or face a new and aggressive regulatory program promised by the SCAQMD. According to the SCAQMD, the Los Angeles-Long Beach port complex is the primary fixed source of air pollution in the Los Angeles basin with > 100 ton/day of NOx emitted.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: News briefs: Sub-Saharan Africa goes lead-free
Abstract: Just a few years ago, cars were fueled with leaded gasoline in all but one of the 49 countries south of the Sahara Desert. Beginning in 2006, however, lead has been eliminated from all vehicle fuels in the region. This accomplishment was the first goal of the UN's Partnership for Clean Fuels and Vehicles (PCFV), which was established at the World Summit on Sustainable Development in 2002 to reduce vehicular air pollution in developing countries. PCFV is now setting its sights on eliminating lead from vehicle fuels worldwide by 2008. Currently, more than 30 countries still use leaded gasoline.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Final rule making findings of failure to submit required state implementation plans for Phase II of the NOx SIP call
Abstract: The EPA is taking final action making findings, under the Clean Air Act (CAA), that Indiana, Illinois, Kentucky, Michigan, and Virginia failed to make complete SIP submittals required under the CAA. Under the CAA and Phase II of EPA's NOx SIP Call regulations, these States were required to submit SIP measures providing for reductions in the emissions of NOx, an ozone precursor. This final rule is effective on 3/10/2006.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Revisions to the California state implementation plan, South Coast Air Quality Management District
Abstract: EPA is taking direct final action to approve revisions to the South Coast Air Quality Management District portion of the California SIP. These revisions concern VOC emissions from solvent degreasers. EPA is approving a local rule that regulates these emission sources under the Clean Air Act as amended in 1990. This rule is effective on 4/10/2006 without further notice, unless EPA receives adverse comments by 3/10/2006.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; Maine; Nitrogen oxides exemption request for northern Maine
Abstract: EPA approves a request for an exemption from the requirements for the control of NOx emissions contained in section 182(f) of the Clean Air Act for northern Maine (specifically Aroostook, Franklin, Oxford, Penobscot, Piscataquis, Somerset, Washington, and portions of Hancock and Waldo Counties). This exemption request is based on a demonstration that NOx in the exemption area are not impacting Maines ozone nonattainment areas or other ozone nonattainment areas in the Ozone Transport Region (OTR) during times when elevated ozone levels are monitored in those areas. As such, additional reductions in NOx emissions from this area beyond what the state regulations already provide for are not necessary for future attainment in any of Maines ozone nonattainment areas or any other ozone nonattainment area in the OTR. This rule is effective on 3/6/2006.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Revisions to the California State Implementation Plan, Ventura County Air Pollution Control District, Yolo-Solano Air Quality Management District
Abstract: EPA is taking direct final action to approve revisions to the Ventura County Air Pollution Control District and Yolo-Solano Air Quality Management District portion of the California SIP. These revisions concern VOC emissions from polyester resin material use operations and organic liquid chemical storage (petroleum liquid storage) and transfer operations. EPA is approving local rules that regulate these emission sources under CAAA. This rule is effective on 4/3/2006 without further notice, unless EPA receives adverse comments by 3/3/2006.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Interim final determination to stay and/or defer sanctions, Yolo-Solano Air Quality Management District
Abstract: EPA is making an interim final determination to stay sanctions based on a proposed approval of revisions to the Yolo-Solano Air Quality Management District portion of the California SIP. The revisions concern Yolo-Solano Air Quality Management District Rule 2.21, Organic Liquid Storage and Transfer. The subjects included in 40 CFR Part 52 are environmental protection, air pollution control, intergovernmental regulations, ozone, reporting and recordkeeping requirements, and VOC. This interim final determination is effective on 2/1/2006.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Revisions to the California State Implementation Plan, Ventura County Air Pollution Control District, Yolo-Solano Air Quality Management District
Abstract: EPA is proposing to approve revisions to the Ventura County Air Pollution Control District and Yolo-Solano Air Quality Management District portions of the California SIP. These revisions concern VOC emissions from polyester resin material use operations and organic liquid chemical storage and transfer operations. EPA is proposing to approve local rules to regulate these emission sources under the CAAA. Any comments on this proposal must arrive by 3/3/2006.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Funding opportunity announcement DE-PS26-06NT15430, enhanced oil and natural gas production through carbon dioxide injection
Abstract: The National Energy Technology Laboratory's Strategic Center for Natural Gas and Oil program mission is to enhance US security by ensuring the Nation has a reliable energy supply. The Strategic Center for Natural Gas and Oil seeks to accomplish this critical goal by advancing environmentally responsible technological solutions that bolster domestic oil and natural gas recovery. Priority will be given to projects in the noted areas of interest - the Williston Basin in North Dakota/Montana and the Cook Inlet Basin in Alaska. This solicitation seeks to maximize US oil and natural gas production in a cost-effective manner through the injection of CO2, while at the same time sequestering significant quantities of CO2. To promote greater use of industrial CO2, additional consideration will be given to those proposals that use anthropogenic CO2 from existing industrial processes for the CO2 flood, e.g., ethanol and gas processing plants, oil refineries, petroleum coke gasification, coal liquefaction, etc. The solicitation will give priority programmatic consideration to projects that involve, in a significant way, existing state/regional institutions that have a mandate or significant interest in supporting enhanced oil or natural gas recovery, and reducing the carbon intensity/CO2 emissions in the state and/or region.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of state implementation plans: Oregon; Portland carbon monoxide second 10-year maintenance plan
Abstract: This action finalizes EPA's approval of the SIP revisions submitted by the Oregon Department of Environmental Quality on 1/3/2005. EPA is approving the State of Oregon's second 10-yr CO maintenance plan for the Portland maintenance area. It is approving the following: Oregon's demonstration that the Portland CO Attainment Area will maintain air quality standards for CO through the year 2017; a revised CO motor vehicle emissions budget for transportation conformity purposes using the MOBILE6.2 emissions model and latest growth and planning assumptions; and revised SIP control strategies and contingency measures. This final rule is effective on 2/23/2006.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; Texas; revisions to control volatile organic compound emissions; volatile organic compound control for facilities in the Dallas/Forth Worth ozone nonattainment area
Abstract: EPA is taking direct final action to approve Texas SIP revisions. The revisions pertain to regulations to control VOC emissions from VOC transfer operations and solvent using processes. The revisions allow use of gasoline vapor recovery systems approved by Texas, and add new requirements to control VOC emissions from motor vehicle fuel dispensing facilities and surface coating facilities in Ellis, Johnson, Kaufman, Parker, and Rockwall Counties. These counties are part of the Dallas/Fort Worth 8-hr ozone standard nonattainment area. The revisions also amend regulations on use of cleaning solvents. The control of VOC emissions will help to attain and maintain the 8-hr NAAQS for ozone in Texas. This approval will make the revised regulations Federally enforceable.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; West Virginia; Emission reductions to meet phase II of the nitrogen oxides (NOx) SIP call
Abstract: EPA is granting conditional approval of a SIP revision submitted by the State of West Virginia. This revision establishes and requires NOx emission reductions from large, stationary internal combustion engines in the State to meet Phase II of the NOx SIP Call. The intended effect of this action is to grant conditional approval of West Virginia's rule to meet its remaining emission reduction obligations under the NOx SIP Call. This final rule is effective on 2/10/2006.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; Maine; 15% and 5% emission reduction plans, inventories, and transportation conformity budgets for the Portland one and eight hour ozone nonattainment areas
Abstract: The EPA is proposing to approve SIP revisions submitted by the state of Maine. These revisions establish a 15% VOC emission reduction plan, and revised 1990 base year emissions inventory, for the Portland Maine 1-hr ozone nonattainment area. These revisions establish a 5% increment of progress emission reduction plan, 2002 base year inventory, and transportation conformity budget for the Portland Maine 8-hr ozone nonattainment area. The intended effect of this action is to propose approval of these plans as revisions to the Maine SIP. This action is being taken under the Clean Air Act. Written comments must be received on or before 2/6/2006.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Revisions to the California State Implementation Plan, South Coast Air Quality Management District
Abstract: EPA is finalizing approval of a revision to SCAQMD portion of the California SIP. This revision was proposed in the Federal Register on 6/14/2005 and concerns particulate matter and ammonia emissions from FCC units at oil refineries. EPA is approving a local rule that regulates these emission sources under the CAAA. This rule is effective on 2/3/2006.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Revisions to the California State Implementation Plan, San Diego County Air Pollution Control District
Abstract: EPA is finalizing approval of a revision to the San Diego County Air Pollution Control District portion of the California SIP. This revision was proposed in the Federal Register on 2/25/2004 and concerns NOx emissions from stationary reciprocating internal combustion engines. EPA is approving a local rule that regulates these emission sources under the CAAA. List of subjects in 40 CFR Part 52 includes environmental protection, air pollution control, NO2, ozone, etc. This rule is effective on 2/3/2006.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans; Tennessee and Nashville-Davidson Couny; Approval of revisions to the state implementation plan
Abstract: EPA is approving non-regulatory revisions to the Tennessee SIP and regulatory revisions to the Nashville-Davidson portion of the Tennessee SIP, submitted by the State of Tennessee through the Tennessee Department of Environment and Conservation on 1/26/99, 10/11/2001, and 4/15/2005. The revisions amend the Vehicle Inspection and Maintenance program in Nashville-Davidson County and the Nashville-Davidson County and the Nashville (Middle Tennessee) 1-Hour Ozone Maintenance Plan. The emissions reductions expected in the Nashville area from expansion of the inspection and maintenance program will be 0.0231 ton/day of NOx and 0.0455 ton/day of VOC. This direct final rule is effective 3/6/2006 without further notice, unless EPA receives adverse comment by 2/2/2006.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: State's rules: Massachusetts - California cruisin'
Abstract: Any car sold in Massachusetts, starting with the 2009 model year, will have to account for greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions. The state's Department of Environmental Protection recently adopted California's vehicle GHG emissions standards. The regulation sets limits on the amount of GHG emissions that can be released from new passenger cars, SUV, and pickup trucks, and is based on an assessment of the various technologies and fuels that can reduce motor vehicle global warming pollutants.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: FCE power plant for California State University
Abstract: FuelCell Energy and its partner Alliance Power Inc have announced the sale of a 1 Mwe molten carbonate fuel cell power plant to California State University, Northridge (CSUN), for a combined heat and power application to help the university meet its goals for greater energy independence, capital growth, cost management, and increased use of green power. The Direct FuelCell® power plant will generate baseload electricity for the university's facilities and surplus heat for hot water. The university also plans to route the exhaust from the heat-exchanger into an adjacent greenhouse and arboretum to enhance photosynthesis, boosting plant growth and harvests by 10-40%. The CO2 enrichment potential provided by the fuel cell may be used for specialized plant research, or as an innovative convention of study within the regular biology academic program. Other university sites with DFC power plant installations include Yale University in Connecticut, Ocean County College in New Jersey, Grand Valley State University in Michigan, the State University of New York at Syracuse, and Chosun University Hospital and Pohang University in Korea. The DFC power plant will be commissioned in the second half of 2006, and operated by CSUN with technical support from FCE and Alliance Power.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Top of the news: The battle is joined
Abstract: During the Senate committee hearing on 3/29/2006 at Capitol Hill, the Renewable Fuels Association (RFA) repeated its debate that there will be enough ethanol to replace the MTBE that is being phased-out of gasoline. The association refuted a report by the EIA that warned that the phase-out of the additive could lead to regional imbalances between gasoline supply and demand and associated price spikes. The EIA identified four areas of impact on gasoline supply from the change: a net loss of gasoline production capacity; tight supply of ethanol and transportation capability; limited resources and permitting issues hampering suppliers' ability to get terminal facilities in place to store and blend ethanol; and some loss of supply from foreign manufacturers. To meet anticipated demand, ethanol suppliers are trucking supply to markets close to ethanol plants, which frees up rail capacity for deliveries further away. Use of MTBE as a gasoline additive will decline in the future. This decline is a direct result of Congress' failure to adopt liability reform provisions for MTBE as part of 2005's energy bill. Meanwhile, a Congressional Research Service (CRS) report sent to Congress in March 2006 suggested that corn-based ethanol would have a limited impact on reducing energy consumption and carbon emissions. The CRS report also indicated that federal incentives for ethanol (tax incentives, reformulated gasoline oxygenate standard) and the renewable fuels standard have promoted significant growth of the ethanol market, boosting US ethanol production from 175 million gal in 1980 to 3.69 billion gal.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: News: NYPA dedicates FCE unit, commissions UTC power plant
Abstract: A 250 kwe Direct FuelCell manufactured by FuelCell Energy (FCE) has been inaugurated at the State University of New York's College of Environmental Science & Forestry (SUNY ESF) in Syracuse. The FCE carbonate fuel cell installed at SUNY ESF will supply 17% of the electricity on campus, as well as providing residual heat for hot water and heating. The college now intends to acquire a gasifier to convert wood residues and biomass into a synthetic gas to drive the fuel cell, instead of the natural gas used to start up the system, taking advantage of the ability of Direct FuelCell power plants to operate on a variety of methane-based fuels. The New York State Energy Research & Development Authority (NYSERDA) provided a $1 million grant for the SUNY ESF fuel cell: the project is also receiving a $250,000 grant from the DOD Climate Change Fuel Cell Program, and a $100,000 grant from the Electric Power Research Institute in California.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Thermoelectric materials, phenomena, and applications: A bird's eye view
Abstract: High-efficiency thermoelectric (TE) materials are important for power-generation devices that are designed to convert waste heat into electrical energy. They can also be used in solid-state refrigeration devices. The conversion of waste heat into electrical energy may play an important role in our current challenge to develop alternative energy technologies to reduce our dependence on fossil fuels and reduce greenhouse gas emissions. An overview of various TE phenomena and materials is provided in this issue of MRS Bulletin. Several of the current applications and key parameters are defined and discussed. Novel applications of TE materials include biothermal batteries to power heart pacemakers, enhanced performance of optoelectronics coupled with solid-state TE cooling, and power generation for deep-space probes via radiolsotope TE generators. A number of different systems of potential TE materials are currently under investigation by various research groups around the world, and many of these materials are reviewed in the articles in this Issue. These range from thin-film superlattlce materials to large single-crystal or polycrystalline bulk materials, and from semiconductors and semimetals to ceramic oxides. The phonon-glass/electron-crystal approach to new TE materials is presented, along with the role of solid-state crystal chemistry. Research criteria for developing new materials are highlighted.
Author Keywords: Energy; Thermal conductivity; Thermoelectricity
Index Keywords: Ceramic materials; Electric batteries; Electric power generation; Fossil fuels; Greenhouse effect; Metalloids; Optoelectronic devices; Thermal conductivity; Waste heat; Ceramic oxides; Electron-crystals; High-efficiency thermoelectric (TE) materials; Thermoelectricity
